title: My Husband Knows Nothing About Soroban â€“ Yet He's Our Kid's Best Study Buddy
description: He can't do Soroban himself, but somehow he's the one keeping our daughter motivated. Here's what he does differently.
imageAlt: Father helping daughter with Soroban practice

content.intro: My husband has never touched a Soroban in his life. He doesn't know the difference between heaven beads and earth beads. Yet somehow, when he sits with our daughter during practice, she's more engaged than when I help her. I finally figured out why.

sections.text: He doesn't try to teach. He just... watches. And asks genuine questions.
"What does that bead mean?" "How'd you figure that out?" "Can you show me slower?"
Our daughter loves explaining things to him. She becomes the teacher. And in teaching him, she actually learns better.
When I sit with her, I try to correct mistakes immediately. "No, not that bead." "You forgot to carry." It feels like pressure.
When Dad sits with her, he has no idea if she's right or wrong. So he just celebrates the effort. "Wow, that's fast!" "You remember all those steps?"
Sometimes not knowing the subject makes you a better learning partner. You can focus on encouragement instead of correction.
Here's the thing: neither of us needs to actually teach Soroban. The Sorokid app does that. It shows each step, gives instant feedback, tracks progress.
Our job as parents isn't to be Soroban experts. It's to be cheerleaders.
What I Learned from My Husband

items: **Ask instead of tell:** "How did you do that?" beats "Do it this way."
**Celebrate effort, not just results:** "You stuck with it!" matters more than "You got it right."
**Let them teach you:** Kids remember 90% of what they teach others.
**Stay curious, not controlling:** Your job is presence, not instruction.

sections.text: You don't need to know Soroban to support your child learning it. Sometimes the best help is just being there, interested and encouraging.

faq.question: Do I need to learn Soroban to help my child?
faq.answer: No. Apps like Sorokid handle the instruction. Your role is motivation and encouragement. Many parents find their kids learn better when they DON'T try to teach.

faq.question: What if my child asks me something I don't know?
faq.answer: Say "I don't know, but let's figure it out together." Or "Show me how you'd solve it." This teaches problem-solving better than giving answers.

cta.text: Want to support your child's Soroban journey without being an expert? Sorokid makes it easy for any parent.
